text.p: Following are the main stories in Wednesday's Malaysian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Malaysia recorded a reduced trade deficit of 954.35 million ringgit in the first 10 months of 1996, compared with 9.96 billion ringgit in the corresponding period in 1995.
-- The driver of a tour bus involved in an accident which killed 13 Singaporeans on December 3 was charged in a magistrates court in the town of Kajang with reckless driving.

-- Tenaga Nasional is installing a computerised Remote Tripping indicator system which will trigger an alarm should tripping occur in its power distribution network. (The move comes after a nationwide power outage on August 3.)

-- Bakun Hydro-Electric Corp, which proposes to be listed on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange, plans to raise six billion ringgit by issuing three billion shares, half of which will come from an initial public offer of 1.5 billion shares, and the rest through a rights issue 12 months after the listing.
-- Malaysian holidaymakers were assured that all is well in Australia despite fears of racial tensions in the country by the South Australian Tourism Commission's general manager in Kuala Lumpur.

-- Most of the 8,000 illegal immigrants currently housed in detention centres in Malaysia will be returned to their home countries later this month, said Malaysian Deputy Home Minister Megat Junid Megat Ayob.
